articles.headline: Fed Officials Hinted They Might Soon Talk About Slowing Bond-Buying
articles.snippet: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s April meeting showed some officials wanted to soon talk about a plan to pull back some central bank support for the economy if “rapid progress” persisted.
articles.abstract: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s April meeting showed some officials wanted to soon talk about a plan to pull back some central bank support for the economy if “rapid progress” persisted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were optimistic about the economy at their April policy meeting as government aid and business reopenings paved the way for a rebound — so much so that “a number” of them began to tiptoe toward a conversation about dialing back some support for the economy.

articles.headline: Ford’s Electric F-150 Pickup Aims to Be the Model T of E.V.s
articles.snippet: If it sells well, an electric version of the best-selling vehicle in the U.S. could help accelerate the move to battery-powered transportation.
articles.abstract: If it sells well, an electric version of the best-selling vehicle in the U.S. could help accelerate the move to battery-powered transportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ford Motor has opened a major new front in the battle to dominate the fast-growing electric vehicle market, and it’s banking on one of the world’s most powerful business franchises.

articles.headline: New Political Pressures Push U.S. and Europe to Stop Israel-Gaza Conflict
articles.snippet: President Biden faces a leftward shift in his party. In Europe, Muslim migration, terrorism fears and populist politics make diplomacy more urgent than ever.
articles.abstract: President Biden faces a leftward shift in his party. In Europe, Muslim migration, terrorism fears and populist politics make diplomacy more urgent than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A diplomatic flurry from the White House and Europe added pressure on Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza on Wednesday to halt their 10-day-old conflict before it turned into a war entangling more of the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: ‘It’s Magic What We Do.’ Movie Theaters Get Starry-Eyed Once More.
articles.snippet: The industry was decimated by the pandemic, with theaters shut across the country and new films delayed by Hollywood studios. But now cinemas are ready to fill up their seats again. Will audiences follow?
articles.abstract: The industry was decimated by the pandemic, with theaters shut across the country and new films delayed by Hollywood studios. But now cinemas are ready to fill up their seats again. Will audiences follow?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s time to go back to the movies! Now!

articles.headline: House Backs Jan. 6 Commission, but Senate Path Dims
articles.snippet: The vote was a victory for Democrats, who were joined by 35 Republicans in pushing for a full accounting of the deadly riot. But Mitch McConnell voiced opposition, clouding Senate prospects.
articles.abstract: The vote was a victory for Democrats, who were joined by 35 Republicans in pushing for a full accounting of the deadly riot. But Mitch McConnell voiced opposition, clouding Senate prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sharply divided House voted on Wednesday to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol assault, overcoming opposition from Republicans determined to stop a high-profile accounting of the deadly pro-Trump riot.

articles.headline: Gaza Conflict Stokes ‘Identity Crisis’ for Young American Jews
articles.snippet: A new generation is confronting the region’s longstanding conflict in a very different context, with very different pressures, from their parents’ and grandparents’ generations.
articles.abstract: A new generation is confronting the region’s longstanding conflict in a very different context, with very different pressures, from their parents’ and grandparents’ generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dan Kleinman does not know quite how to feel.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Countries Are Scrambling for Vaccines. Mongolia Has Plenty.
articles.snippet: By playing off its big neighbors, Russia and China, Mongolia has emerged as a positive outlier among developing nations on the hunt for shots.
articles.abstract: By playing off its big neighbors, Russia and China, Mongolia has emerged as a positive outlier among developing nations on the hunt for shots.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mongolia, a country of grassy hills, vast deserts and endless skies, has a population not much bigger than Chicago’s. The small democratic nation is used to living in the shadow of its powerful neighbors, Russia and China.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Case Throws Abortion Into 2022 Election Picture
articles.snippet: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights say a major ruling just before the midterm elections could upend political calculations for the two parties.
articles.abstract: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights say a major ruling just before the midterm elections could upend political calculations for the two parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Within hours of the Supreme Court accepting a case that could lead it to overturn or scale back a landmark abortion rights ruling, Senator Michael Bennet, a Colorado Democrat facing re-election next year, issued a dire warning to supporters: The fate of Roe v. Wade is on the line.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Is It Time to Panic About Inflation? Ask These 5 Questions First.
articles.snippet: Focus on exactly how and why prices are changing over time, and how these shifts might affect you.
articles.abstract: Focus on exactly how and why prices are changing over time, and how these shifts might affect you.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand why inflation is so worrying to so many people, you could look at price charts for lumber or used cars or New York strip steaks. There is no doubt that the prices of many of the things people buy are rising at an uncomfortably rapid rate.

articles.headline: Once Tech’s Favorite Economist, Now a Thorn in Its Side
articles.snippet: Paul Romer’s call for government activism, particularly toward the big tech companies, reflects “a profound change in my thinking.”
articles.abstract: Paul Romer’s call for government activism, particularly toward the big tech companies, reflects “a profound change in my thinking.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Romer was once Silicon Valley’s favorite economist. The theory that helped him win a Nobel prize — that ideas are the turbocharged fuel of the modern economy — resonated deeply in the global capital of wealth-generating ideas. In the 1990s, Wired magazine called him “an economist for the technological age.” The Wall Street Journal said the tech industry treated him “like a rock star.”

articles.headline: As Paycheck Protection Program Runs Dry, Desperation Grows
articles.snippet: Overwhelmed lenders and panicking borrowers are in a frenzy to grab the remaining money in the small business relief program.
articles.abstract: Overwhelmed lenders and panicking borrowers are in a frenzy to grab the remaining money in the small business relief program.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s $788 billion relief effort for small businesses ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic, the Paycheck Protection Program, is ending as it began, with the initiative’s final days mired in chaos and confusion.
